com.emc.pravega.stream

Interface EventRead<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the event.

    public interface EventRead<T>
    An event read from a stream.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      T getEvent()
      Returns the event that is wrapped in this EventRead.
      Sequence getEventSequence()
      Returns a sequence that events are ordered by.
      java.lang.Long getOffsetInSegment()
      Returns the byte offset within the segment the event was read from.
      Position getPosition()
      The position in the stream that represents where the reader is immediately following this event.
      Segment getSegment()
      Returns the segment the event came from.
      boolean isRoutingRebalance()
      Returns a boolean indicating if a rebalance of which events are being routed to which readers is about to or needs to occur.

    • Method Detail

      • getEventSequence

        Sequence getEventSequence()
        Returns a sequence that events are ordered by. This can be used to align events from different readers. Sequences returned have the guarantee that it will always increase for consecutive calls to EventStreamReader.readNextEvent(long) unless the previous call set isRoutingRebalance() to true. (When rebalancing occurs on a reader in a ReaderGroup this reader could have acquired more segments of the stream from another reader that was behind) If all of the readers in a group have passed a certain value, it is guaranteed that no event will ever be read below that level. The highOrder value of the sequence is approximately the time the event was written to the stream. The sequence has nothing to do with any sequence passed to EventStreamWriter.writeEvent(String, Object) The value will be populated on all calls to EventStreamReader.readNextEvent(long) even if getEvent() is null because no events are available. The value will continue to increase even when no events are available. This is useful as it can bound the values associated with future events.
        Returns:
        sequence object, a wrapper for 2 numbers, which are'high order' and 'low order'

      • getEvent

        T getEvent()
        Returns the event that is wrapped in this EventRead.
        Returns:
        the event itself.

      • getPosition

        Position getPosition()
        The position in the stream that represents where the reader is immediately following this event. It is useful to store this so that ReaderGroup.readerOffline(String, Position) can be called if the reader dies.
        Returns:
        position of the event

      • getSegment

        Segment getSegment()
        Returns the segment the event came from.
        Returns:
        segment object where the event resides

      • getOffsetInSegment

        java.lang.Long getOffsetInSegment()
        Returns the byte offset within the segment the event was read from.
        Returns:
        long event offset in the segment

      • isRoutingRebalance

        boolean isRoutingRebalance()
        Returns a boolean indicating if a rebalance of which events are being routed to which readers is about to or needs to occur. For a reader that is part of a ReaderGroup this means the next call to EventStreamReader.readNextEvent(long) this reader may receive events from a different set of RoutingKeys. Once this reader calls EventStreamReader.readNextEvent(long) some of the routing keys it was previously reading may be taken over by another reader. This is relevant if the reader processes events in a way that involves holding state in memory. For example an app that is maintaining counters in memory for different types of events should interpret this boolean as an indication that it should flush its values to external storage, as the set routing keys it is working with are about to change. For a reader that is not part of a ReaderGroup and is rebalanced manually, this means the application should call RebalancerUtils.rebalance(java.util.Collection, int) with the positions of its readers and recreate new readers from the resulting positions. It is the goal of the implementation to not set this to true unless it is required.
        Returns:
        boolean whether a rebalance is being routed
